PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: F.M. Knecht
Address: 105 Ave O, Saskatoon
Birthplace: Pembroke, Ont

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1898
Where did you set up housekeeping? One mile east of Rutherford
Where had you been living before that? In the Village of Saskatchewan
For how many people did you prepare meals? Batched
How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? The same as now except that jam was sold in 7 lb wooden pails, syrup in bulk, also soda biscuits

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvie
In what quantities did you buy it? Bought 100 lbs (my dad at least)
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.95
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? P.A. How far away? 9 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75 cents
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? None Whole Wheat? None Farina? None
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? We had a coffee mill for coffee

(Please excuse writing as I am very nervous)

F.M.K
1898. Kusich, F.M.
103 Ave. O. South, Saskatoon.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? In what town?

We always had Christmas dinner never failed. Remember about 1896 Mr. John & Mrs. and wife just came from England. My mother had them as guests the first year too.

19. Have you ever refused to accept assistance? If so, why?

We are all over weight any one starved at their own risk. To bury it any neighbor through illness or hard luck was well taken care of. Almighty God we didn't appreciate the almighty dollar those days.
